article_title: Obamacare can save small businesses serious money
article_text:
Obamacare can save small businesses serious money

Photo: Bob Levey, Photographer Small-business owners across Houston will soon get renewal notices...

In the next few weeks, small-business owners across Houston will get renewal notices for the group health insurance policies they offer employees. Inevitably, it'll contain higher premiums.

article_metadata.description: In the next few weeks, small-business owners across Houston will get renewal notices for the group health insurance policies they offer employees.  Federal subsidies available through Obamacare, more often than not, make premiums for an individual insurance policy lower than those for a small group health plan, said Mike Stahl, senior vice president at HealthMarkets.com, a nationally licensed insurance agency with 3,000 agents representing 140 insurance companies.  Brokers with his Dallas-based company specialize in helping individuals and small businesses evaluate and buy plans, and they are increasingly recommending that small firms drop group health coverage.  Employers have the choice of keeping the savings, offering higher pay, contributing to a health savings accounts or adding benefits, such as adding dental, vision or life insurance.  Kimberly Gonzalez, owner of Houston's Platinum Copier Solutions, said she's tried to provide health insurance since she started the business eight years ago, but with only 13 workers who have varying needs, it was a nightmare to find and maintain a group plan.  Called the Small Business Health Options Program, or SHOP Marketplace, it allows employers to leverage the federal health care marketplace to find inexpensive plans, contribute to their employees' premiums and give workers more plan options.
article_metadata.author.name: By Chris Tomlinson
